title: Before 2018, will Russia officially announce that it is suspending its participation in or withdrawing from the New START treaty?
preds:
Comments: RU strategic systems in fast-paced optimization. See RU withdrawal from Treaty as minimal and probability of suspension rising incrementally over the next 12 - 18 months.     
Defense Update, December 31, 'New Weapons Initiatives Violating Strategic Arms Control Treaties': http://defense-update.com/20171231_inf.html
Clip from article:
"As Russia continues the modernization of its strategic forces, Moscow is testing the limits of compliance to arms reduction treaties it is committed to."
I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

Putin just announced yesterday that he wouldn't. Even though he is building his arsenal and re-building underground C2 facilities, he has been doing this for the past few years and it is easy to remain within the treaty while not really following the rules. Gains nothing by getting out of them.

Russia says it is fully committed to nuclear missile pact
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-usa-nuclear/russia-says-it-is-fully-committed-to-nuclear-missile-pact-idUSKBN1E30HZ

Russian President Vladimir Putin blasted the United States for failing to meet nonproliferation commitments and warned that Russia would have an “immediate and reciprocal” response if the United States withdraws from the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty.
https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2017-11/news/putin-slams-us-nonproliferation-deals

Comments: Russians have a fuller understanding of how Americans think and act (slow, with a LOT of talk) and USA vs RU military capability. Let's say they'll stretch and knead the truth to their benefit for as long as we let them.
The Hill, November 9, 'Defense bill wouldn't limit extension of arms treaty with Russia': http://thehill.com/policy/defense/359709-defense-bill-would-not-limit-extension-of-arms-treaty-with-russia
Clips from Hill article:
"While the Russian Federation appears to be moving toward compliance with the limits laid out by the New START Treaty, the Russian Federation cannot be allowed to comply only with treaties that suit its interests and violate those that do not,” House and Senate negotiators wrote in a conference report released Thursday. “Treaties are not negotiated and ratified independently but in the context of the range of arms control agreements in force.”
Comments: Important to note the word 'appears'. We really don't know with an absolute certainty.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Comments: In compliance (maybe). 
The Independent Barents Observer, October 4, 'Russia is close to fulfill New START Treaty - Since July, Russia’s strategic nuclear force is reduced by 204 warheads. In the north, though, no reduction is seen': https://thebarentsobserver.com/en/security/2017/10/russia-close-fulfill-new-start-treaty
Clip from Observer article:
"There are no reports on reduction in warheads deployed on the Sineva- and Bulava missiles carried by the Russian navy’s fleet of Delta-IV and Borei-class submarines. It is therefore reasonable to believe that the reduction counts for less warheads deployed on land-based ballistic missiles, either in silos or mobile based."
Comments: Hard to verify compliance on a ballistic missile sub, at least not by satellite or fly-overs.

Comments: Looks like the Russians have a full testing schedule. Increased survivability, accuracy and lethality in next-gen systems appear to be the goals. 
The Diplomat, September 28, 'Russia Tests Topol-M Intercontinental Ballistic Missile - The purpose of the missile launch was reportedly to test advanced ballistic missile warheads': https://thediplomat.com/2017/09/russia-tests-topol-m-intercontinental-ballistic-missile/
Clips from article:
"The goal of the launch was to test advanced ballistic missile warheads,” a Russian MoD spokesperson told TASS news agency. The missile’s warhead successfully destroyed a maneuver target at the Sary-Shagan range in Kazakhstan. The data gathered from the launch will be used to develop advanced anti-missile defense penetration aids, the spokesperson added.
The nuclear-capable Topol-M (aka RS12M2/NATO reporting name SS-27) is a three-stage solid fueled ICBM first test launched in 1994. It has a reported maximum range of about 11,000 kilometers (6,835 miles) and can carry a single 550 kiloton nuclear-tipped warhead. The missile can also be upgraded to carry independently targetable warheads."

They will just cheat. Again. They always have, always will. The state (security services) broke in to WADA drug testing facilities to cover up for their doping 'athletes'. If you cheat in sport you'll cheat in anything. Such sore losers these vodka-soaked Ruskis, it's hilariously sad.

Rather than withdraw they will argue that they are being bullied by the U.S. and change their definitions to appear to comply so why quit?
Still, even the designation of the missile is in dispute, as Russia calls it a brand-new missile while the U.S. insists that it is a variant of the Topol M, forbidden under arms-control treaties.
http://www.defenseone.com/technology/2017/09/russians-just-test-fired-icbm/141163/?oref=d-river&utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=DFN%20DNR%209.21.17&utm_term=Editorial%20-%20Early%20Bird%20Brief

Comments: Nebulous language. In the meantime, progress on expansion/enhancement of strategic systems continues.
Xinhua, September 13, 'Moscow ready for talks with U.S. on extension of New START Treaty': http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-09/13/c_136606142.htm
Clips from article:
"In fact, the New START Treaty, in force until 2021, has an option of being extended for a five-year period. We have not made our minds yet, but we are ready to consider this option, at least, to discuss it with the U.S. side," Ulyanov said.
Ulyanov added that in order to begin negotiating the treaty's extension, Washington should indicate that it considers the possibility to extend the pact."

Comments: Playing the long game. Smart.
Scout.com, September 9, 'The Russian Military's Greatest Enemy - For several years now, Moscow has been trumpeting its development of sophisticated next-generation weapon systems that finally put the superiority of Western': http://scout.com/military/warrior/Article/The-Russian-Militarys-Greatest-Enemy-And-Its-Not-America-107135992
Clips from article:
"The Russian military is also doing just fine with various types of missiles. Forget the S-500, the S-400 SAM system already poses a significant challenge to contemporary fourth-generation fighters. The Iskander ballistic missile could hit European capitals from the Russian enclave in Kaliningrad. The Kaliber cruise missile is a combat-tested as Tomahawk-equivalent, and comes in a deadly anti-ship variant which the Russian Navy has installed on small corvette-sized ships, giving them heavier armament than anything on the U.S. Navy’s frigate-sized Littoral Combat Ships. And of course, Russia’s nuclear ballistic missile arsenal remains the underlying concern in any clash with Moscow, regardless of its conventional forces."
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Comments: On ground and in air, tactical moves to attain strategic objectives. Continue to see same with ballistic missile forces. Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
NBC News, August 2, 'Russia Plans Huge Zapad 2017 Military Exercises With Belarus': https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/russia-plans-huge-zapad-2017-military-exercises-belarus-n788741
Clips from NBC article:
"Russia is not organizing defensive operations but instead an offensive threat, testing how serious we are about protecting the members of NATO," said Jonathan Eyal, international director of the Royal United Services Institute, a London-based think tank.
Belarus not only borders Russia, but also three of America's key but relatively isolated NATO allies: Poland, Lithuania, and Latvia.
The latter two were occupied by Soviet forces for almost 50 years and they have remained a focus of the renewed standoff between Russia and the West. This breakdown was sparked by Moscow's 2014 annexation of Crimea and worsened over military intervention in Syria and allegations of state-sponsored hacking.
"Russia is reminding us that the Baltic states are relatively indefensible," Eyal added. "They want to see where the cracks are in NATO and where they can be widened."
Adjusting down for the passage of time.

Dropping from three to zero because Russia's strategy right now seems to be step back and watch the US government tear itself apart. I don't think they want to draw attention to themselves.

The National Interest (analysis), May 10, 'Nukes, Subs and Missiles: How Russia Plans to Challenge America's Military Dominance': http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/nukes-subs-missiles-how-russia-plans-challenge-americas-20622
Clips from NI article:
"The Russian response to the Pentagon’s Third Offset Strategy has been to prioritize the development of tactical and strategic nuclear weapons argues a new report from the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies (IDSS) at the Singapore-based S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies. But while the Kremlin is prioritizing the development of new nuclear weapons as competition in the conventional arms race speeds up, Moscow is also pursuing its own military innovations albeit on a smaller scale.
“Russian responses to counter these initiatives consist of two major elements: The first one is ‘countering the Third Offset Strategy with the First Offset Strategy’, which means prioritising the development of a wide array of both strategic and tactical nuclear weapons systems,” wrote Michael Raska, a professor at IDSS, and Vasily Kashin, a senior research fellow in the Institute of Far Eastern Studies in the Russian Academy of Sciences. “For Russia, maintaining a sophisticated arsenal of nuclear weapons can effectively offset conventional military innovations of the U.S., NATO, and China. The second element of the response strategy is more ambitious, and carries greater technological risks. Russia began to counter many U.S. technological initiatives via similar indigenous programs, although more narrowly focused and smaller in scale.”
Washington Examiner, April 29, 'Russia weighs heavily in America's nuclear plans': http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/russia-weighs-heavily-in-americas-nuclear-plans/article/2621340
Russia does not need more strategic intercontinental missiles. At the same token, it wont reduce any as well.
(no change) The US nuclear review will be interesting.

Interesting opinion piece:
Newsweek, April 12, 'THE U.S.-RUSSIA NUCLEAR ARMS RACE IS OVER, AND RUSSIA HAS WON': http://www.newsweek.com/us-russia-nuclear-arms-race-over-and-russia-has-won-581704
Clips from article:
"President Trump reportedly told President Putin, during their January 28 conversation, that the current arms control treaty, up for renegotiation in 2018, was one-sided in favor of the Russians. With all due respect to Trump, his American-centric view of the Obama-era arms agreement is moot; the U.S.-Russian arms race is over, and Russia has won.
The RS-28 missile will be operational next year; the new American land-based ICBM won’t be operational for another decade. Russia is on the verge of deploying a hypersonic, missile silo-killing weapon that undermines the secretary of defense’s thin justification for a new land-based ICBM.
Every missile system Russia deploys, or will deploy, is capable of defeating America’s missile defense systems, including what is currently deployed and what is envisioned for the future. And Russia is on the verge of completing the deployment of its own anti-missile shield, one that will seal off its air space to bombers, cruise missiles and ballistic missiles, negating in totality America’s nuclear triad."
Down 5% for passage of time. One can only handle so many issues at one time, especially if encumbered by gum or native talent.

The Hill, April 4, 'Top general: Russia treaty under review is not the one Trump attacked': https://www.google.com/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=missile+launch&tbm=nws
Clips from article:
"Separately, Russia is on track to comply with the New START Treaty, and the military is not reviewing that agreement despite President Trump's criticisms of it, Stratcom commander Gen. John Hyten told the Senate Armed Services Committee.
“I have not been directed to review the New START agreement,” Hyten said Tuesday. “I am reviewing the INF agreement based on the recent Russian activity.”
"Hyten said all indications are that Russia will meet its obligations by 2018."
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Down 10% to be nearer the consensus. Not sure the US national security team will be sorted out and functional in time to try any gambits that might trigger a Russian response.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Laboratory Equipment, March 24, 'Nuke ‘Super Fuze’ Triples ‘Killing Power’ of U.S. Missiles': https://www.laboratoryequipment.com/news/2017/03/nuke-super-fuze-triples-killing-power-us-missiles
Clips from article:
"The “super fuze” that’s now incorporated on U.S. submarines worldwide has essentially tripled the “killing power” of the U.S., achieving insurmountable superiority against other nuclear powers, including Russia, the former Cold War adversary.
“This vast increase in U.S. nuclear target capability, which has largely been concealed from the general public, has serious implication for strategic stability and perceptions of U.S. nuclear strategy and intentions,” writes Hans Kristensen, director of the Nuclear Information Project with the Federation of American Scientists, in the assessment of the new arsenal.
The new mechanism was developed in the 1990s, and since 2009 has been incorporated on all of the U.S. Navy’s W76-1/Mk4A warheads.
Essentially, the new fuze allows greater accuracy over “hard targets,” such as Russian ICBM silos. The fuze does this since it does not have fixed height-of-burst parameters – and instead adapts upon re-entry to almost ensure its greatest lethal payload is focused on the target below.
Instead of needing three standard submarine-based missiles, then, destruction of a priority target would only take a single missile, writes Kristensen."
Incremental adjustment down for the passage of time.

RS-28 Sarmat: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RS-28_Sarmat
The RS-28 Sarmat (Russian: РС-28 Сармат; NATO reporting name: SATAN 2), is a Russian liquid-fueled, MIRV-equipped, super-heavy thermonuclear armed intercontinental ballistic missile in development by the Makeyev Rocket Design Bureau from 2009, intended to replace the previous R-36 missile. Its large payload would allow for up to 10 heavy warheads or 15 lighter ones or up to 24 hypersonic glide vehicles Yu-71, or a combination of warheads and massive amounts of countermeasures designed to defeat anti-missile systems; it was heralded by the Russian military as a response to the U.S. Prompt Global Strike.

"Russians made a really different design choice than we did" when it came to building ICBMs, said Lewis.
"Russia built nuclear weapons that are incremental improvements," he said, or weapons that would need updating every decade or so.
On the other hand, "US nukes are like Ferraris: beautiful, intricate, and designed for high performance," he said. "Experts have said the plutonium pits will last for hundreds of years."
Indeed, the US's stocks of Minuteman III ICBMs, despite their age, are "exquisite machinery, incredible things."
"Russia's nuclear weapons are newer, true," Lewis said, "but they reflect the design philosophy that says, 'No reason to make it super fancy because we'll just rebuild it in 10 years."

(no change) Just wondering what some action/terminology such as a "pause" related to New START would mean for this question. There are any number of political or military actions that might warrant something similar to the NATO Article 4 consultation. One example would be to temporarily halt withdrawing older weapons pending some "review." I believe some to'ing and fro'ing is almost normal course related to how the Bilateral Consultative Commission conducts business. My guess is that it would qualify as "suspending" since there are no time criteria specified.
Interesting 'fact check' in light of the Presidential debates regarding Russian obligations under New START:
Just for reference on Russian nuclear policy generally, here's an article from the WSJ on the INF:

During the debate, Clinton said explicitly that "highest levels of the Kremlin" means Putin himself. That means that he can't get away with firing someone important, a "diplomatic apology" in that vein would be something amounting to a coup, which is just more difficult to pull off. Furthermore, it also makes it clear that the US has a grudge with Putin, not with the Russian state, which might do something to internal Russian politics and Russian/Putin-allied states. That means that getting alliances to do something is going to be that much more difficult to pull off, which means that Putin is more likely to do something unilateral, like make decisions regarding participation in START.

The arms race did not work for them when they were the Soviet Union, being a financially poor country which cannot afford it, and that the US could walk away, Russia cannot suspend it. I agree with that view.

While the "Cordon Sanctionaire" is still problematic for Russia, both politically and economically, the lost of prestige from withdrawing from such a symbolic treaty effort is not worth it. Sure, the Cold War never really ended and may well be picking up but, after all, you don't have to withdraw from a treaty formally to violate it.

The central limits in New START on strategic delivery vehicles and strategic warheads reflect Russian interests, so why abrogate a treaty that preserves Its interests and does not hamper modernization.  Besides, Putin recently acknowledged Russia's desire to avoid a new cold war.  Putin can capitalize on nuclear modernization within treaty limits and preclude touching off an arms race with a struggling Russian economy.  On balance, a win-win for Russia.
Easier to obfuscate and test the limits than to actively withdraw. The threat is worth so much more than the action itself.

Putin is nasty but neither stupid nor crazy.  These treaties provide him with a low-cost fig leaf of international respectability for one thing, and for another he doubtless recalls that the last arms race ended badly for his beloved USSR.  He can always violate them and deny it or redefine the relationship, since most of what he does and all of what he says is aimed primarily at his domestic audience, who are required by law and threat to believe him.  That general approach seems to work pretty good for him.
